questions.text: A 32-year-old construction worker presents with right shoulder pain after falling from scaffolding 3 hours ago. Physical examination reveals a squared-off shoulder appearance with the arm held in slight abduction and external rotation. X-rays confirm anterior shoulder dislocation without fractures. Neurovascular examination is normal. Pain management has been provided, and the patient consents to reduction. What is the most appropriate reduction technique?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The Hippocratic technique is not routinely recommended because it is associated with a high rate of complications compared to other available techniques.

B) INCORRECT:

The leverage technique involves using the arm as a lever against a fulcrum, which can result in excessive force and increased risk of fracture or neurovascular injury. This technique is not recommended for shoulder reduction.

C) INCORRECT:

Traction-countertraction is a technique that is equally effective as other methods. However, this technique specifically requires two providers to perform, and another equally effective single-provider technique is available.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Scapular manipulation is one of the recommended reduction techniques for anterior shoulder dislocations. All recommended techniques are considered equally effective with minimal complications. This technique can be performed with the patient prone or upright and involves medial rotation of the scapula while applying anterior traction to the affected arm.

E) INCORRECT:

The Kocher technique is not routinely recommended due to higher pain, time to reduction, and failure rates compared to other techniques. This technique may be associated with more complications than the recommended techniques.
